title: Are there any famous authors you hate? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Hate” is a strong word, as is “famous,” though he is an NYT bestselling author so that’s probably more famous than I’ll ever be. His name is Andrew Gross, and I feel closer to mild disgust and disappointment than hatred for the guy. It was at a writer’s convention, with keynote speakers Mary Kay Andrews, the aforementioned Andrew Gross, and some guy called Bob Stein. Andrews kicked it off Friday night with just the kind of speech you expect at a conference geared toward authors struggling to begin their careers. I’ll probably mangle it, but she told us how she’d struggled for years as a journalist before realizing she wasn’t paying her dues, she’d already capped out and was always going to be relegated to the trash beats while worse journalists would be promoted by virtue of their chromosomes. She told her editor she was quitting to be a novelist. He told her she’d never make it because she was a shit writer and no one would want to read her fiction. She went after it anyway, saddened and discouraged to learn her journalism hadn’t prepared her for fiction as well as she’d thought. She stuck with it after a failed first manuscript or two and finally, starving and desperate, she sold one. It had a limited run and didn’t sell as well as she’d hoped but after a long time, struggling all the way, she carved out a sustainable living, only to change her pen name and brand ten years in and basically start over. She’d survived the loss of her very dear, favorite editor and continued to write novels, some of them best sellers, up until today. The moral could hardly have been more explicit if she’d outright said it; it won’t be easy but if you work harder than any sane person is willing to work, you just might be a moderate success. Standing ovation, tears in the crowd, etc. Then there’s Mr. Gross. He showed up to his author’s panel in the morning still drunk from the night before, and slurred awful advice when he bothered to talk at all, which we kind of wished he hadn’t. He did sober up for his speech that evening, but he clearly hadn’t prepared anything. He recognized Andrew’s inspiring story from the night before, and decided he’d spitball his own journey into being a novelist. He too came into it late, having been raised in Westchester, attended Columbia, and starting out on a career as CEO to dying companies. He pulled three from the brink of bankruptcy, each endeavor more extreme and difficult than the last until he burned out on business. He hated his life, hated that he never got to see his wife, and fell into depression. I should note, I was with him up to this point. Sure, he had a pedigree and a pretty cushy life, but that came with high expectations and pressure, and who doesn’t feel for a depressed guy who wants more time with his wife? But then he said it; “I wanted to do something easier,” and I thought “oh boy, I hope he’s not going to stick with that assertion.” He did. He wrote a thriller and since he knew a guy who knew a guy (of course he did), he was able to get an interview with a guy who had an interesting business proposal. So that’s how this unpublished hombre who dashed off a novel on a lark got to sit across a table from one James Patterson, who didn’t like the whole novel but did think there was some good dialogue, so they could do business. Patterson has a plot outlined and he wanted Gross to write it, Patterson would take credit for it, Gross would get an upfront fee and that would be that. Gross agreed. That wound up being a bestseller. Gross wrote a few more for Patterson before getting sick of having no credit and a fraction of the profit, so he got second billing a couple times on novels that were basically all his before breaking clean from the Patterson brand and going it alone. That’s it. The story kind of trailed off from there. I don’t hate him, but he did kind of give us all a kick to the balls. He could have spun it more to his favor, if he was a decent storyteller and had an ounce of self awareness, he would have. Instead he implied writing fiction is way easier than we make it out to be, and churning out bestsellers is just a cool hobby you can enjoy after you’ve made your fortune. His was not a popular table at the signing.

I can’t say I hate Steven King, but I try my best to avoid his writings, for the most part. “Danse Macabre” is a good guidebook for writers. His other books are too long and involved to interest me. “The Stand” goes over 1200 pages, for example. It involves too much for me to digest and after it was done I could stand [pun there] and wonder what I had gotten out of a long, involved book. Nothing

V.S Naipaul perhaps who is often not just downright rude and insulting but offensive towards his readers, despite the greatness of his writing.Another write r would be Salman Rushdie who comes across as cocky and lacking in humility,on several occasions.Quite unattractive traits in a writer who writes so sensitively.

Yes there are. Durjoy Dutta and Chetan Bhagat. One can learn nothing from their books and you get the most clichéd kind of stuff strewn all over them which are too shallow, at least according to me. It makes me wonder sometimes what a hapless state the readers of India are in and I feel so ashamed that it is our country who has nurtured the growth of these amateurish writers. Mr. Bhagat may be an excellent orator but writing, I feel, is just not his cup of tea. Thanks for the A2A. Sneha.
